Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister must consider humanitarian and compassionate circumstances before referring a case to an admissibility hearing
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 44
Crimes.Application_Facts: Correia was convicted of cocaine importation and reported as inadmissible due to serious criminality
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review based on lack of humanitarian consideration, bias, and insufficient reasons
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds are not considered at the referral stage under IRPA s. 44
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident or foreign national subject to removal
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation of procedural unfairness and failure to consider humanitarian factors
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Interpretation of statutory authority under IRPA s. 44
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Factual basis of serious criminality without humanitarian assessment
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Scope of delegate’s authority at referral stage
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal conviction record for cocaine importation
Crimes.Application_Basis: Well-founded report of inadmissibility due to serious criminality
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Set aside referral decision and require humanitarian assessment
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Minister may refer well-founded reports of serious criminality without H&C assessment
Crimes.Cause_Description: Conviction for cocaine importation leading to inadmissibility
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to immigration control due to criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Minister to refer without H&C assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Sufficient factual basis established for referral
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Legislative intent limits referral stage to administrative and factual review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Controlled Drug and Substances Act violation
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility arising from drug-related criminal conviction
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether humanitarian and compassionate grounds must be considered prior to referral under IRPA s. 44
Crimes.Governing_Law: Controlled Drugs and Substances Act, IRPA s. 44
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction for cocaine importation accepted as conclusive
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Rule: No requirement to assess humanitarian factors at referral stage
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of fairness in referral without H&C consideration
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No duty of fairness requiring H&C consideration at referral
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities (in criminal context, proven beyond reasonable doubt)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Convicted and did not dispute criminal facts
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention to halt removal process
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Controlled Drugs and Substances Act, IRPA s. 36(1)(a) and s. 44
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Non-citizen with permanent resident status at risk of removal
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Serious criminality due to drug importation
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Referral under IRPA s. 44 is fact-based and does not require H&C evaluation
